title: Corpora in Greater Gandhāra: Tracing the Development of Buddhist Textuality and Gilgit/Bamiyan Manuscript Networks in the First Millennium of the Common Era
descriptions:
The proposed project, "Corpora in Greater Gandhāra: Tracing the Development of Buddhist Textuality and Gilgit/Bamiyan Manuscript Networks in the First Millennium of the Common Era," aims to investigate the evolution of Buddhism through the analysis of textual material in Indic languages from the first millennium of the Common Era. Recent discoveries at the Mes Aynak archaeological site in Afghanistan and a private collection in Thailand have provided valuable insights into the manuscript type, predominantly the Gilgit/Bamiyan type sūtra manuscripts. The geographical coverage of the study includes Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Northern India.

Through a combination of philological, paleographical, codicological, and critical research methods, the project will focus on textual and material production, transmission, and relationship networks. The expected outputs include the creation of a digital archive, an akṣara database, digital preservation, editions and translations, and feature studies on textual, paleographical, and codicological aspects. Additionally, content comparison across multiple languages will be conducted.

This project will contribute to a deeper understanding of the development of Buddhism in Greater Gandhāra and shed light on the manuscript networks in the region during the first millennium of the Common Era. The findings will be valuable for scholars and researchers interested in Buddhist textuality and manuscript traditions.
